captions.text:
Artistic Association
of Writers and Filmmakers

Based on the works by
M.A. BULGAKOV

Chief Military Consultant
General I. PAVLOVSKY

Ludmila SAVELYEVA
as Serafima Vladimirovna Korzukhina

Alexei BATALOV
as Sergey Pavlovich Golubkov

Tatiana TKACH as Lyuska
Vladislav DVORZHETSKY as Khludov

Also starring
R. KHOMYATOV as Frunze

V. ZAMANSKY as Bayev
N. OLYALIN as Krapilin

V. OSENEV as Tikhiy
A. YANVARYOV as Golovan

V. BASOV as Artur Arturovich,
Cockroach Tsar

O. YEFREMOV as Colonel
Alyosha NAUMOV as Petka Shcheglov

P. SHPRINGFELD as Skunsky
N. SERGEYEV as Undertaker
I'd just like to help you.

I wonder sometimes
whether I'm dreaming.

You're not well!
You're burning up.

Give me a little water!
Your canteen!
Watch them naked in the cold!

The best Italian
troupe from Vyazma!

Sorry to interrupt you, Your
Excellency. The Reds are in the city.

General Krapchikov,
the cards are dealt.

That's it! Hurray!
Long Live the Land of Soviets!

Let's run, Madame.
This way, Madame, this way.
Charity, in the name of Christ...

Prince Vladimir,
pray to the Lord for us.
O Lord, have mercy on us...

Saint Prophet and Baptist John,
pray to the Lord for us.
Have mercy, O Lord, have mercy...

All right, come on.
Did you light a fire on the steeple?

- Did you signal with torches?
- There's no one here but the monks.

We were caught by gunfire
and came here to the monastery.

That's a woman,
she's about to give birth.

- Here, her passport.
- About to give birth...
Where did these Reds come from?
Why did all this have to happen?

- A fur cloak and hat.
- Cloak and hat!

And you, civilian worm,
I bet you're a prosecutor?

I'm not a prosecutor, I'm a privat-
docent. We're fleeing from Petersburg.

I'm wife of Undersecretary of Trade,
Serafima Vladimirovna Korzukhina.

These are my false papers,
but I have real ones, too.
Noah's Ark. Strike up the band!

Cossacks! We've beat General
Charnota back from the Reds!

We were about
to hold a burial service for you.

I was as close to death
as I am to you now.
Let go of me. I'm cold.
Can you imagine such a story...

As soon as I arrived at Headquarters,
to General Krapchikov,

the son of a bitch
made me play cards with him.

He'd just got a dispatch, but he
postponed its decoding till morning.

And there came Budyonny out of
the blue.

I fled by backyards
to a citizen Barabanchikov.
Give me your papers, I say.

I crawled back here, looked at
the papers - they were woman's,
And a certificate that she's pregnant.

Well, I said, put me down,
as I am, here in the church.

So I'm lying and giving birth.
Got so cold!
Where are you clicking to, I think.

Here is your death lying under
the horse-cloth. Come on, lift it.

He took my passport,
but didn't touch the cloth.
We must get over to Crimea.

Have you gone mad?
That ceremony can wait.

We have to scarper.
A Red Army corps is at our heels.

General, listen!
You've got to take her with you.

Serafima Vladimirovna is ill.
I know you have an infirmary.

Yet you give me the impression of
an absolutely illiterate man.

An infirmary's going to be of no help
if you get a bullet in your head.

We have to take her. Can't leave
such a pretty woman to the Reds.

- Please, General.
- All right, to the wagon.

Come, my dear,
we have permission. We must leave.

You go ahead, Sergey Pavlovich.
I'd better lie down. I'm so hot.

I'm thirsty.
I want to go back to Petersburg.

- Oh God, what's the matter with her?
- It's typhus, that's what it is!

- Krapilin, persuade the lady.
- That's right, we've got to go.

We've got to go!
Please, help me.

General, won't you stay and fight for
the monastery that offered you shelter?
Why are you upsetting me, father?

Tie up the tongues of your bells
and move into the cellars!

Ho! Go straight ahead!
Don't wait for us!
The light. Turn off the light.

the Azov Fleet
can't leave Taganrog.

The temperature is -15°C, the sea is
covered with solid ice.

The fleet is physically
unable to come

has made it impossible for us
to attack on the left flank.

Therefore the only line of attack is
against the Turkish Wall, head on!

And through the Sivash marsh,
with the fifteenth

and fifty-second divisions attacking
the Perekop grouping from the rear.

I personally will give orders to
the troops at the starting positions.

We start operations on the seventh,
at twenty-two hundred hours.

By tonight, Army commanders
will have received my orders.
I'm very worried about the infantry.

To cover seven miles through half-
frozen mud. They will freeze.

They'll be icicles on the other side,
which can be broken with a finger.
I see what you're driving at, Bayev.

A horse is no fish,
the water is no place for a horse.

Support our spearhead
with my cavalry regiment.

It's true that as a Red officer
I've never avoided glory.

And on the eve of the third
anniversary of our revolution,
I'd like to drink a toast with you

of a little Sivash marsh water,
that is if you're willing to share it.

- Don't forget the brass band.
- I won't forget.

- Well, how does it look?
- I washed it as well as I could.

The Commandant and Station Master
to report to the Front Commander!

The Commandant and Station Master
to report to the Front Commander!

But Frunze won't play the role of the
designated adversary for our maneuvers.

This is not a chess game, nor our
unforgettable Tsarskoye Selo.

Code it
and send it to the Commander in Chief.
And that's how our tragedies start.

Our armored car is limping with
a stick.
No one loves us. No one.

A solid hour I've waited for that
train to Taganash.

What's wrong?
What's wrong? What's wrong?

The stationmaster has convinced me
that the ''Officer'' can't get through.

You have proved that the armored
train can't get through?

Yes, sir. There is no
physical way to do it.

We've sidetracked everything we can.
The way out is blocked.
Then the second one is smoking.

Just a minute.
Put the fire out.

It seems to me, I don't know why,
that you rather like the Bolsheviks.

Don't be afraid,
speak to me honestly.

We all have a right to our own
opinions.

I haven't slept for thirty hours.
I have two children, Olya and Pavlik.

But what you need is love. Without
love, you can't do anything in war.

Push them, sidetrack them, but in 15
minutes get it past the semaphore.

the commandant shall be shot
and the stationmaster hanged.

Their corpses will bear
the inscription: ''Sabotage''.

Your Excellency,
my children don't go to school yet.

What does he think he's doing?
What is he doing? Come on, move!

The combined cavalry division from
Chongar defile reporting for duty.

You're a member of our General
Staff, Your Excellency.

Leave the wagons here. Go to Karpov
Gully and take your position there.

The wagons and the wounded will stay
here. You're staying, too.

They're coming out on Litovsky
Peninsula.

I've been delegated by the Council of
Ministers to put 3 questions to you.
The first one concerns five workers

who were arrested in Simferopol.
What's happened to them?

Lieutenant, present the prisoners
to the Undersecretary.

- If you'll follow me.
- Very kind of you.

Is that a satisfactory reply?
The second question?

What?
The second? Oh, of course.

We hear that here, in this station,
you're holding up vital cargo.

I beg Your Excellency
to take required measures

to have these goods shipped
at once to Sevastopol.

It's furs for export.
For use as foreign exchange.

Ah, furs for export.
What train are the furs in?

Golovan! Have the train sidetracked,
soak the goods with gas and burn them.

What could it possibly be?
A mess. Big guns firing.

Commander of the front
has a smelly stove.

No restaurant, no girls.
You could die of boredom here.

Sitting like big baboons on our
behinds.

Go to Sevastopol
and tell that fat bunch of cowards

that they'd better pack.
The Reds will be here by dawn.

You can add that there'll not be any
fur muffs for their foreign strumpets.

- Furs for export!
- This is an outrage!

You can be sure that I shall
inform the commander in chief.

- Feed her.
- Take her and feed her.
Will you please come with me.

Last time we met on Dmitrovka,
he didn't have time either.

Hey, hey! What are you doing?
Get away from there! Out!

We've fled from Petersburg.
All the way from Petersburg.
All we hear is Khludov, Khludov...
We even see Khludov in our dreams.

Finally we have the honour to see
the great general.

Bloodsucker! You jackal! They are
coming to finish you all off!

Are you out of your mind?
Let go of me!

Let go!
Look, she's no communist!

She's the wife of Korzukhin!
She doesn't realize what she's saying.

because when you realize what you're
talking about, all you get is lies.

So that scoundrel has a communist
wife, eh? How lucky!

- Are you Paramon Ilyich Korzukhin?
- That's correct.

Your wife's come from St. Petersburg
to join you.
I've never seen that woman before.

I don't know any Serafima...
Vladimirovna.

I wasn't expecting anyone from
Petersburg. She's an impostor!
Take her away and question her.

Your Excellency,
this is a misunderstanding.
Like it's written in books. Ajackal!

You can't win a war
by hanging men.

Why have you massacred men
at Perekop, you beast?
And here a woman comes along

and pities all those hanged,
that's all she did.

But no one can get away from you,
you grab them, and in the bag they go!

He has expressed some very
lucid opinions on war.
Get a sack and a board.

What's in a name? Nobody knows me.
I'm Krapilin, an orderly.

But you, monster,
will end up in a ditch.
Sit on your barrel for now.

You're just brave enough to hang
women and unarmed workers.

I attacked the Chongar trenches with
music! I was wounded in action.

But everybody in Russia
spits on your music!

Goodbye, Your Excellency,
I've said everything.
A good start, but a very bad end.

Hang him.
I can't bear the sight of him.

Stand back, gentlemen!
Clear the way! Stand back!

I beg leave to present
my report confidentially.

Three hours ago the Bolsheviks
took Yushun. They've entered Crimea.

- It's the end!
- It's the end.

In these dark hours, the mercy of
God Almighty is our only hope.

why do you ply your children
with new trials?

You're disturbing the Lord in vain,
for He has long since abandoned us.

We couldn't do a thing.
Sivash marshes dried overnight.

The Bolsheviks walked over it
as if it was the floor.

Saint George seems to be mocking
our army.

Such a tone is unbearable.
General, it appears you're very ill.

You should have gone abroad for
treatment, as I advised you.

Then who would have made your
soldiers defend the Perekop Wall?

Who would have sent Charnota
to Karpov Gully?

Who would have had men hanged,
Your Excellency?

You must return
to Sevastopol at once.

Gentlemen, the Commander
in Chief is leaving us.
Clear the way! Clear the way!

Get away from here!
What's the matter with you?

Dismantle the headquarters at once.
Crimea has been surrendered.

Get back to your units immediately.
Defend the station by all means.

I order that not a single soldier
remain alive.
Born an artillery man to be,

The Guards School cadets
There march and sing.

Trumpets and drums
And cymbals are ringing!

Maids and laundresses,
Cooks and milliners,
All they gaze at the marching cadets!

Our orders are
to boost morale, Colonel.

In the last hours,
our position,

and I might say, the entire strategic
position of southern Russia

has been undergoing a very rapid
change.

We suggest that
you rip off all your insignia
and then each go his own way.

- But this is a betrayal.
- Treason.

- What is this?
- Calm down, gentlemen!

I have no time
and I assure you, you haven't either.
Whom are you trying to defend?

I'd like to know what it is
you want to defend?

- Russia!
- You know that Russia's against us.
Only the echo of our steps.

- But we have our orders!
- Whose orders?
Orders of the Commander in Chief.

From the Commander in Chief?
That's just what I thought.

The Commander in Chief has fled,
shamefully abandoning us to our fate.

He fled like the lowest
scoundrel and coward.

And so has the general in command
of this front, Khludov.

Within hours we'll be witnessing
the ultimate catastrophe.
Now listen to me, young men.

who has lived through the war against
the Germans,
So, I'm sending you home now!

Colonel, sir! I refuse to go.
I'm staying with you.

As for me, sir,
on behalf of the young cadets

that I misled into staging
that ugly demonstration,
My feet. A memento of the shackles.

A message to General Wrangel,
Commander of the Southern Forces.

To General Wrangel.
Don't you hear well?

your army by protracted, senseless
and hopeless resistance to our forces

will only succeed in prolonging
this utterly useless bloodshed.

For this reason, I propose
that you cease all resistance.

If you judge that this
proposal is acceptable,

I declare that the Revolutionary
Military Council of the Southern Front

conferred upon it
by the Central Soviet Government,

shall guarantee to all who surrender,
a full pardon

of all crimes committed
in connection with the civil war.

Couldn't find a chair, but I found
a bed.

Thank you, Comrades.
You can sit down, too, Comrade.

Remember that in your hands are
the lives of thousands of people

who have been drawn into the fight
against Soviet Russia.

Should that fair
proposal be refused,

all the responsibility for senseless
shedding Russian blood

Commander-in-Chief of the Southern
Front, Mikhail Frunze.
Look, who's that man standing there?

There's no one there,
Your Excellency.

You don't see anyone?
Come here, sit down.
I'm sorry, I don't see anyone.

There's no one there,
Your Excellency.

Krapilin's been hanged.
He couldn't be standing there.

Yes, you may go.
Oh no, wait...

That's a book, the Bible,
Your Excellency.

Archbishop Afrikan sent it as a gift.
I reported it to you.

I'm so bored.
Read some of it aloud.

I'm sorry, Your Excellency,
I never learned to read.
If the blind leads the blind,
both will fall into a ditch.

I'm sorry, Your Excellency,
I don't know.

If you say so,
Your Excellency.

I want you to stay, Lieutenant.
Don't leave.

Tell me who is out there?
Soldier! I know you're here!
Damn, crazy things in my dreams.
Did you dream when you fell asleep?

Sorry, Your Excellency,
I dreamed about a woman.

Don't you ever have
any heartache, Lieutenant?

Maria Konstantinovna,
I couldn't sell a thing.

Careful, with all these horses.
Allow me to help you. Your foot.

I'm sure you understand how important
it is for us to know the truth.

There are all kinds of nasty
rumors about counter-espionage.

has a very difficult task to perform
for the security of the state.

- Care for a smoke?
- Thank you, I don't smoke.

- Tell me what did you do with her?
- With whom?

You must understand that
this is an absurd situation.

I'm sick and tired of that comedy.
Who told you to sit down? Stand up!

You must tell nothing but the truth.
If you start lying...

- Do you hear?
- I have never lied.

All right, no back talk!
Just answer my questions!

For what purpose did you enter
the White Command Headquarters area?

For what purpose did the so-called
Serafima Korzukhina arrive here?

I'm sure, I know it,
she's really Korzukhina.

But Korzukhin said before your eyes
that it's a lie.

He was lying.
He was just afraid.

Write. I'll dictate to you.
It'll be easier.

But I'm warning you, if you stop
I won't answer for the consequences.

Ready? ''I, the undersigned,
Sergey Pavlovich Golubkov,

''Entered the region occupied by the
armed forces of the South of Russia

to engage in Communist propaganda
and join underground groups.''
Thank you for your honest testimony.
Gurin! Take him outside. He can go.

What do you suppose Korzukhin
will give to buy it back?

Here in the Crimea?
Ten thousand dollars.

I would advise you to get
Korzukhina sign a confession.

Delay Korzukhin boarding
the ship for at least an hour.
Gurin, take that paper away from her!

Look at what they
made him write!

We demand that you evacuate the
premises of counter-espionage at once!
Fell in love with her a page...

Buy a house. I'll take any foreign
currency, even if it's counterfeit.

Merciful Lord, this is absurd.
What am I doing here?

Be quiet, Your Excellency.
Let me listen.

But you'll have to admit
I'm in an incredible situation.
Oh, good heavens! What a fool!

I'm Undersecretary of Trade.
You'll regret this.

I'm going to the toilet.
I hope you don't mind?

- What are you doing here?
- Waiting for the Commander in Chief.

You'll wait here until the Reds
come. Onto the ship!

The Commander in Chief isn't
receiving anyone.
I was waiting impatiently for you.

The cavalry had a very bad time
on the way.

But generally speaking, everyone got
away.

Sitting quietly in the corner of
a compartment.

Didn't bother anybody.
Nobody bothered me.

Twilight everywhere
like in a kitchen.

Once at nightfall I went to
the kitchen.

I struck a match, and all of them
scattered.

I heard their feet pattering,
scratching, scraping.

We're like them,
scurrying in the dark.

I look and wonder where we're
fleeing to?

Like cockroaches, we'll fall from
the kitchen table into the bucket!

for everything you, with your
great strategic talent,

I'm not going to detain you any
further.
Myself, I'm moving at once to a hotel.

If you keep forgetting your manners,
I'll have you arrested.

My men are in the vestibule. Better
not to cause a scandal. I'm popular.
No, it's not your poor health.

For a year your
loathsome antics have been hiding
the hatred you feel for me.
I do hate you, it's true.

I hate you for having
involved me in all this.

Where are the armies the allies were
to send us?

How could you start fighting them
when you are powerless?
You are the cause of my illness.
But now time's up for us both.
We shall both drop into oblivion.

I shan't keep you any longer,
General.

Turning out your most obedient
servant?

I was told that I could come
to see you.

about ghastly crimes committed
in the counter-espionage services.

And the cause of those crimes
is General Khludov.
You haven't been hanged, have you?
So what are you complaining about?
I must say you make a good impression.
If you please, state your grievances.
You ordered a woman to be arrested.

But may I ask to whom did you
wish to complain about me?

There's no longer anyone you can
complain to about General Khludov.

Take a guard, go to counter-espionage.
There's a woman I had booked there,

If she hasn't been shot,
bring her to the palace.

- If you had her shot...
- Try to be a man.
If she's not alive, I'll kill you.

Well...
it might be the easiest way out.

Try to understand, soldier, you got
under the wheel which has ground you

It's no use following me,
do you hear?

- Are you speaking to me?
- What?

She won't come, she is no more.
She's been shot.
What is she to you? Your mistress?
No. Someone I met by chance.

- Has she been shot?
- No, sir.
Why haven't you brought her here?

- Excuse me.
- You can speak before him.

General Charnota burst in, removed
the prisoner by force, took her away.

To steamship ''Vityaz''.
At five it weighed anchor.

So she is alive.
Your woman, Serafima, is alive.

Lieutenant, take the flag
and embark on the ''Prelate''.

Khludov, take me along with you
to Constantinople.

Oh damn, what's it all about?
Serafima, Constantinople...

We got to hurry.
Everybody's already fled.

Three coffins, the best ones,
and a lacquered hearse with tassels.

The undertaker is here,
Your Excellency.

Now I'm going to announce
my last order to the regiment.

We've got nothing left,
no flag, no army, no country.

I have led you along
the path of lies.
It's my fault, it's my sin.

to survive this terrible time
in Russia's history.

We have chosen that option of our
own free will.
Do us a favour, my dear man.
Three men will have to be buried.

Don't worry, everything will be
done first class,

Don't worry, my dear man,
we'll pay you well.
But you must do your duty honestly.

- Give him the money, Captain.
- Yes, sir.

Have pity, Your Excellency.
Let me go, I'm not guilty of anything.

Don't be afraid, my dear.
Nobody wants to harm you.

On the contrary, you're going to earn
a fortune. After all, it's yourjob.

Of course, I'll be glad to.
Whom shall I have to bury?

Idiot! You will bury whoever
is to be buried.
You shall bury us, my dear.

Us.
These two gentlemen and myself.

Are you out of your mind,
you scoundrel?

They are unshaved. They'd better be
shaved alive, or it'll be difficult.
It's none of your business. Shut up!

Captain, you're reeking of vodka.
Shame on you.
